title: 107_s3088
content: The Act titled "Reservists and Guardsmen Pay Protection Act of 2002" ensures that federal employees in the uniformed services or National Guard will not have their pay reduced while performing active service. The "Reservists and Guardsmen Pay Protection Act of 2002" guarantees that federal employees serving in the uniformed services or National Guard will not experience a pay reduction during their active duty. This includes receiving basic pay for each pay period they would have received if their civilian employment had not been interrupted. The "Reservists and Guardsmen Pay Protection Act of 2002" ensures that federal employees in the uniformed services or National Guard do not face a pay cut during active duty. Payments under this act are made for each pay period the employee is entitled to reemployment rights under chapter 43 of title 38, and does not receive basic pay for that period. The Reservists and Guardsmen Pay Protection Act of 2002 guarantees that federal employees in the uniformed services or National Guard do not experience a decrease in pay during active duty. Payments are made by the employing agency in accordance with regulations set by the Office of Personnel Management and the Secretary of Defense. The Reservists and Guardsmen Pay Protection Act of 2002 ensures that federal employees in the uniformed services or National Guard do not face a pay cut during active duty. The Office of Personnel Management, in consultation with the Secretary of Defense, will establish regulations for implementation. Each agency mentioned in the act must develop procedures to guarantee employee rights, and the Federal Aviation Administration must also ensure employee rights are protected. The terms 'employee', 'Federal Government', and 'uniformed services' have specific meanings as defined in section 4303 of title 38. The Reservists and Guardsmen Pay Protection Act of 2002 defines key terms such as 'employee', 'Federal Government', 'uniformed services', 'service in the uniformed services', and 'employing agency'. It also includes provisions for basic pay and reemployment rights under chapter 43 of title 38. The Reservists and Guardsmen Pay Protection Act of 2002 includes provisions for nonreduction in pay while serving in the uniformed services or National Guard. The effective date for these amendments is pay periods beginning on or after September 11, 2001. Additionally, the act adds a Ready Reserve-National Guard employee credit to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Ready Reserve-National Guard employee credit under section 38 allows for a 50% credit of actual compensation for qualified active duty. The credit is limited to 12 months and does not apply on days when the employee was not scheduled to work. Qualified active duty is defined as specified in the section. The term 'qualified active duty' refers to active duty that entitles an employee to reemployment rights and benefits under certain codes, excluding training duty. Compensation is defined as remuneration for employment deductible by the taxpayer. Compensation is any remuneration for employment deductible by the taxpayer. A Ready Reserve-National Guard employee is a member of the Ready Reserve or National Guard. The terms 'National Guard' and 'Ready Reserve' have specific meanings under title 10, United States Code. The amendment to section 38 of the Code includes a credit as part of the general business credit. The amendment to section 38 of the Internal Revenue Code includes a credit for Ready Reserve-National Guard employees, as defined in title 10, United States Code.
